dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue sky, a few puffs of cloud, pierced by slanting rays sunlight. Late afternoon on a perfect day.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER TITLE
dialogues.text: As we hear, after a few more beats, an ASTRONAUT'S VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: T minus ten, nine, eight, start  ignition sequence, five, four, three,  two, one, ignition... Liftoff!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny red streak zips into the sky, then bursts with a f ludicrous POP. A bottle rocket. We hear CHILDREN'S LAUGHT excited SHOUTS.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LAWN PARTY. LUKE GRAHAM'S HOUSE. LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: DESCENDING, we see PHIL OHLMYER, late 20's, kneeling, wit gaggle of eager CHILDREN around him. Phil, an astronaut, got an impressive array of fireworks lined up, and is usi an empty longneck as his launching tube.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (all at once) My turn! My turn! No, I was next!  No, me! Uncle Phil, Uncle Phil, can  I do one? I want to do one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys, guys, please! This is risky  stuff here. And I'm a highly trained  professional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derisive GROANS from the kids, more SHOUTS. Phil grins.  There's little danger NASA will ever use him on a recruit poster: he's messy, very hyper. Phil waves his hands for  silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay! Uncle Phil will launch  another booster...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another astronaut, RENEE COTE, a tall, very fit French wo is walking by with a fresh six-pack. She tosses a beer an Phil catches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...just as soon as he completes his  fuel intake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who grins, walking away from Phil and the kids, as we beg to get a better sense of the scope of this party. We are the big back yard of a middle-class home in a Houston sub DOZENS OF PEOPLE - astronauts, NASA personnel, and their  families -- are gathered around picnic tables or spread-o blankets. Lots of red, white and blue bunting, lots of  balloons. We hear snatches of MUSIC, mostly country-flavo from dueling boomboxes. Futuristic Frisbees are being tos about. A banner, strung between trees, reads "BON VOYAGE,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll take us six months just to get  to Mars. Another year on the surface,  then six months back. That's two  years...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passing the banner, Cote lobs a beer to another astronaut NICHOLAS WILLIS, who snags it neatly. He's got his other around the waist of a PRETTY GIRL. As Cote moves OUT OF F ANGLE LINGERS on these two. Willis, a very young astronau early 20s, is recruiting poster material, and knows it al too well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess what I'm trying to say is,  since this is my last night on Earth,  it's gonna be a very precious memory  to me. Y'know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice try, Nick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Pretty Girl slips out of his grasp, laughing, and  walks away, Willis shrugs philosophically. He pops open h beer, swigs it. ANGLE FOLLOWS THE PRETTY GIRL As she swerves around an op pit barbecue, where other ASTRONAUTS are gathered. Cote h paused here, too, distributing the last of her beers. SER KIROV, a Russian cosmonaut, is watching some kids nearby they play a game of wiffle ball. He turns, grinning beeri at the chef.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Woody, our Mars One crew won't  be heading back to Earth till ten  days after you guys land at our base  camp with Mars Two. That's a pretty  good long rendezvous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOODY BLAKE, late 30s, is a big, rangy guy in a cowboy ha over a Hawaiian shirt and a "KISS THE CHEF" apron. An ent pig is turning on a spit over the flames, and Woody is ba this as he smiles at Malik.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you suggesting, Sergei?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you should bring a baseball  bat. Yes? American baseball? Our two  crews could have ourselves a little  Solar System Series.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. Half you guys are foreigners.  We'd crush you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, we have equal crews. Three  men, one woman. Same handicap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grins teasingly at Cote, who makes a face at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy now, you're talking about my  wife. (seeing her approach) And Terri just happens to be one  helluva shortstop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. TERRI FISHER, early 30s, passes by with a platter of  corn-on-the-cob. Short, sturdy body, a face made attracti by its alert, questing intelligence. She pauses to kiss  Woody's cheek; there's a wonderful, sexy spark between th Then she glances at Kirov, all business now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fast pitch, no steals, batter calls  his own strikes. Thousand bucks make  it interesting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a bit rattled by her cockiness, and looks at Cote, w smiles, nods her cool agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh bien. Winner take all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. (smiles sweetly at  Kirov) Bring some balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other men ooooh at this, busting on Kirov and Cote, a Terri moves on. Woody, watching her go, has a thousand-wa grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna know the sad part?  Technically I outrank her. But if we  want any peace at all on Mars Two,  I'm gonna be saying a lot of "Yes,  dears."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others laugh. ANGLE FOLLOWS TERRI as she dodges a PACK OF KIDS -- they by her, shrieking happily - before she finally reaches a  picnic table, where ASTRONAUTS' WIVES are opening contain of baked beans, coleslaw, and potato salad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...just not sure how I feel about  NASA allowing couples to go on this  type of mission together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the other women raises a warning eyebrow, and the Wife turns, sees Terri setting down her platter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Nothing personal, Terri. It's just  that, well, it's kind of a funny  feeling for those of us staying  behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully neutral) All the research shows that marriage  will provide stability on these long  duration trips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then they haven't studied some of  the couples I've known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter at this. Terri smiles politely -- she doesn't re have much in common with these women -- before moving on. ANGLE LINGERS on the wives, who watch her go with a sligh tinge of jealousy. One of them is looking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody seen Jim McConnell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think he's coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, that poor man. How's he doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally losing it, from what I hear.  Can't sleep, can't eat. Visits her  grave almost every day. (lowers her voice) They say he could lose mission status.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's so sad. That is just so  tragic. You go to a routine physical  one day, and wham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all those years of training,  too. It was their whole dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be a pretty funny feeling for  Luke Graham. Y'know? Now he's gonna  be in the history books. First man  on Mars...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head, awed by the thought. The others nod agreement, following her glance... In the distance, a lone MALE FIGURE stands by the garage, his back to them, facing the parked cars, vans, and SUVs  which stretch down the driveway and along the street. Ano figure, a WOMAN, can be seen approaching him. CLOSER ANGLE FOLLOWS the moving woman -- DEBRA GRAHAM, ea 30s, very attractive -- until she reaches her husband. LU GRAHAM, mid 30s, has the lean, fit body of an astronaut, restless intellect of a scientist. He's unaware of her  approach until she touches his shoulder. He looks at her  with an apologetic smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not coming, Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim deserves this, too. All his  friends are here. And it's my last  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) Your last night with us, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her, moved. She summons a smile. He slides hi arms around her waist, kisses her forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Deb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you too, baby. But maybe you  should spend some time with Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I will. Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up in his fort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her again, then goes. Debra's eyes follow him,  with a mixture of pride and sadness. ANGLE FOLLOWS Luke away from the garage, into

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE BACK YARD. LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Luke moves through the crowd. Phil and the kids are still shooting off rockets. Red streaks arc high overhead. In the back corner of the yard, where it's quieter, he pa Willis, who's sitting on a blanket, murmuring soulfully t PRETTY GIRL #2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deep space is so lonesome. So cold.  But I guess I'll have my memories to  keep me warm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke shakes his head. Willis is incorrigible. Finally he  reaches a tall redwood playset. He looks up the ladder. A SMALL BOY sits on the platform of the tower, arms aroun his knees, staring up at the stars. A telescope rests nea on a tripod. He looks lonely. Luke climbs up, sits down on the wooden deck next to him. BOBBY, 7, glances over at his dad, his idol, then back at the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's gonna read to me now, at  bedtime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke is surprised by the question. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like when you do it. Now we're  never gonna finish our book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice is unexpectedly fierce. He's fighting back tear Luke is moved. Another brief silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll tell you what. I've been  thinking about that. And what I  thought was -- how 'bout if I bring  along my own copy? (Bobby looks at him) Then every night, wherever I am,  I'll read a little bit more of it.  And I'll know that you and Mommy,  wherever you are, you're reading it  too. That way, it'll feel like we're  still reading it together. 'Cause I  don't know about you, but I'm pretty  anxious to find out how 'ol Ben Gunn  got marooned on that island. What  d'you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby manages a smile. He nods, feeling a little better.  Luke is proud of his son's courage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good deal. Can I have a hug?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby's arms go around his father's neck. He hugs Luke  fiercely, and Luke hugs him back. His eyes, over the thin young shoulders, are brimming with love and impending abs Then, from the distance, the sound of an APPROACHING CAR. They both turn. An open Jeep is coming down the street. Its DRIVER is alo Luke's expression changes. Recognition, then happiness.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LUKE'S STREET. LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: The Jeep stops, its electric engine WHIRRING down. The Dr climbs out wearily, reaching into the back seat, and come out with a champagne bottle, hastily decorated with ribbo The PARTY SOUNDS are drifting this way, and he hesitates moment, seeming to gather himself. He starts gamely towar the party, then pauses again. Debra Graham stands nearby on the front lawn, waiting. Sh smiles tentatively. JIM MCCONNELL, early 40s, manages a smile in return. He h dark circles under his eyes, and his clothes look slept i Yet we sense, even through his sadness, a kind of quiet  competence in this man, an unforced authority; he's a nat leader. Debra hurries forward, into his arms, and he hugs her. Th separate, looking at each other. Her eyes are shining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were afraid you wouldn't come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I caught a whiff of your barbecue.  After that I was helpless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the way out in Galveston?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like that. (she smiles) It's his night, Deb. I didn't want  to spoil it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spoil it? He's been going crazy  looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over her shoulder he sees Luke approaching, his arm aroun Bobby. The two men look at each other, the bond between t so strong it needs no words. Finally Luke smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon. A whole lot of folks here are  gonna be mighty glad to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McConnell comes towards him, accompanied by Debra, and  together the four of them move OUT OF FRAME, heading towa the party. ANGLE HOLDS on the parking area, as we...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SAME VIEW. NIGHT, (HOURS LATER)
dialogues.text: All the parked cars and vans are gone now, except for two McConnell's Jeep and Woody's classic 'Vette. Willis, one the last to go, is just departing on his motorcycle. Perc behind him, arms around his waist, is PRETTY GIRL #3. The zoom away, through the darkened neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BACK YARD. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The yard is nearly deserted. The "Bon Voyage" banner has  torn loose at one end and flutters limply. Here and there napkin blows across the ground. In the distance, THREE FIGURES sit on the ground, by the  waning fire of the barbecue pit, sipping beers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Woody shoves another piece of wood into the flames. Fo moment he, McConnell, and Luke are silent, staring at the sparks as they rise towards the stars -- red and gold dot mingling with the silver ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abruptly) I wish we were all going. Together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The intensity in his voice surprises the others, and even Woody himself. Luke glances at McConnell. An awkward beat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you've got a short memory. Think  back to how we were by the second  week of lunar training.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're not gonna bring that up  again --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) I'm trying to remember, let's see,  which one of us scored the lowest  ranking up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just can't let that go --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, man, three commanders, on the  same ship? If they sent us off to  Mars together, there wouldn't be  enough fuel to lift all those egos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Bullshit, we would've made a great  crew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was never gonna happen. I was  always teamed with Maggie, and we  were mostly chalkboard jockies. You  know? Systems. Payloads...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to him. Mr. Cover-of-Time  Magazine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, who landed the crippled Block  II Shuttle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and who scored highest on the  lunar rankings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let it go, Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Sure, I made a little noise. But  putting the first footprints on Mars?  Nah. That's for guys who... (looks at Luke) ...wrote their Ph.D. thesis on how  to colonize the place. And guys who... (looks at Woody) ...read too much science fiction as  a kid and still wear little Flash  Gordon rocketships around their necks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs playfully at Woody's neck. Woody smacks his hand away, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You read the same damn science fiction  books that I did! You're just not  man enough to wear jewelry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls from his shirt a little Flash Gordon rocketship  emblem hanging on a chain, and waggles this tauntingly at McConnell, as Luke and McConnell laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want Flash. You know you want  him. Well you'll have to come through  me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke grabs Woody's arm to give McConnell a better shot at the emblem, but Woody cuffs his hands away, laughing.  McConnell, watching their horseplay, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, she would've loved to see you  two clowns. Just one more time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to smile, but his face reddens. Then all at once his chest is heaving as he struggles to control his emoti Woody sees this, reaches out a reassuring hand, but McCon shakes him off, rises abruptly. He turns his back on them walking away a few steps. Woody and Luke exchange a worried glance.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LUKE'S STREET. LATER THAT NIGHT
dialogues.text: McConnell and Luke watch as Woody starts up his Corvette. McConnell has regained his composure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Woodrow, isn't it about time  you donated this thing to a museum?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody revs the engine, which ROARS lustily. He grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Internal combustion, boys. Accept no  substitutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke laughs. Woody looks at McConnell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, if there's ever... if there's  anything Terri and I can do --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay. Really. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody reaches out to shake Luke's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you when I get to Mars, Luke.  Don't solve all the mysteries of the  universe, okay? Leave a little  something for the next guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see what I can do. Just make  sure you bring some fresh beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a final glance at McConnell, Woody slips the car int gear. McConnell and Luke watch as he drives away. A silen Luke glances at his old friend, growing more serious. We  sense he's been waiting all night for a chance to say thi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should've been your mission, Jim.  Yours and Maggie's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McConnell, looking after Woody's car, becomes very still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of us ever wanted Mars the way  you two did. Not even Woody. Twelve  years of hoping for this assignment,  training for it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all over now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Maggie hadn't gotten sick -- if  you hadn't pulled yourself out of  the rotation to take care of her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McConnell turns to him, his eyes flashing danger. He will not tolerate pity. Luke sees this but presses on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm gonna say this. I have to  say it... (pause) I wanted Mars One. Hell, I battled  you for it every step of the way.  Never wanted to beat anybody so bad  in my life. But not like this...  Jim, I'd give this all up in a second,  if it would bring Maggie back to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McConnell is deeply moved, and for a moment doesn't trust his own voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that, Luke. You don't have to  say it... Mars is yours now. Go get  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Take care of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. You too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke nods. They grab hands for a second, then let go. Luk walks back towards his house. McConnell watches him for a moment, then turns, walks over to his Jeep. He opens his  door, then pauses. He turns. Looks up at --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny reddish dot hovers there, glowing steadily. Mars  itself, a tantalizing prize. But for him now, more distan than ever. For him, perhaps, never to be attained.

dialogues.speaker: MCCONNELL'S FACE
dialogues.text: As we see these thoughts going through him. After a momen he looks down at

dialogues.speaker: HIS SHOES
dialogues.text: And the sandy verge of the front yard.

dialogues.speaker: MCCONNELL'S EYES
dialogues.text: Are a map of complex emotions: regret, injured pride, inf yearning. Gently, a bit self-consciously, HE LIFTS ONE SH And sets it down again, making a careful, deliberate foot in the sandy soil...

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARS. CHRYSE PLANITIA. DAY
dialogues.text: Instantly we're hurled into an immense, stunning LANDSCAP mysterious and vivid as a fever dream. Dazzling sunlight. vast plain of rust-orange soil. Countless craters. Boulde the size of houses, tossed about by the hands of gods. Tw moons hanging in a salmon-pink sky. On the horizon, tower craggy peaks. And, at center -- the only sign of life -- small, mysterious, moving puff of dust.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARS. DAY
dialogues.text: CLOSER ANGLE as a small, Sojourner-like, multi-wheeled ro vehicle ambles INTO FRAME, jouncing along the orange Mart soil, pausing to snuffle its sensors towards the occasion interesting rock. Lettering on its side reads "ARES-8."

dialogues.speaker: SUPER TITLE
dialogues.text: Suddenly Ares-8 pauses. Its video lens WHIRRS out, fine-t focus, as it becomes intrigued by something OFFSCREEN -- higher, more distant target. The little fellow almost qui with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARS. TIU VALLIS. DAY
dialogues.text: A one-man ATV ROVER waits in the background, in a dry  streambed, as Luke, in an EVA spacesuit, swings a clawed  rock hammer against a multi-layered, sedimentary rock fac Reddish dust coats his bulky white suit. Despite that bul he moves easily in the light Martian gravity (1/3 Earth's A hunk of rock breaks off, and Luke examines it more clos holding it up to his clear faceplate. He's very happy,  absorbed in this work, when his RADIO CRACKLES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke, you read me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Renee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke, I just got ARES-8 on line and...  Well, we think you're gonna wanna  see this for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke, though reluctant to break off work, is intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Copy that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Luke turns away, headed for the rover

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To REVEAL a STAGGERING PROSPECT, seen for the first time: Valles Marineris, that planet-creasing slash. So wide, so deep, it boggles the mind: on earth it would reach from N York to L.A.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MARS ONE HAB. DAY
dialogues.text: The crew of Mars One - Kirov, Willis, and Cote -- have jo Luke, gathered around some display monitors. They're in N jumpsuits; the Hab has artificial atmosphere, enhanced  gravity, and heat. All are captivated by what they see. O

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO SCREEN
dialogues.text: We see a low-angle image of an elongated, rubble and dirt covered MOUNTAIN. Hard to tell scale, but it looks huge.  What's most striking, however, is a WHITE PEAK barely  protruding through the rubble two-thirds of the way along the mountain's ridgeline. Its whiteness is in clear contr to the typical rust-orange of the surrounding rubble; wha more, this strange little peak also displays an oddly-smo multi-planed symmetry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No idea, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cote glances at the others. They're all smirking, as if t share some secret joke Luke's not yet in on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't wanna know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, what's so funny? Gimme the  coordinates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans over to read a digital gauge, but Cote covers it with her hand, enjoying the tease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latitude 41 degrees north, longitude  9 degrees west.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Plains of Cydonia. So? (pause) Oh no. You're not telling me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all laugh as the other shoe drops. Luke's expression incredulous, exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oui. Exactement! It's Kirov's fault,  he picked today's sector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, c'mon! We've got a scientific  duty to check that thing out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke sits, taking over the Ares remote control from Cote. They all watch as he fine tunes the image, trying without success to coax more resolution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. That's great. The first anomaly  we hit, and it's gotta be in the one  place guaranteed to make NASA look  ridiculous... You know how many books  have been written about that damned  mountain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Egyptians put it there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the Amazons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it was little green men!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And all because a couple of lousy  impact craters happen to look like  eye sockets. If this gets out, we'll  have every UFO kook on Earth spouting  off on the six o'clock news... C'mon,  people, gimme a read here. Is that a  cinder cone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, too smooth. Too angular. Volcanic  upwelling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No fissures. No caldera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an upwelling, for sure. But  maybe not volcanic...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others look at him, puzzled. Luke leans in closer, wi growing excitement. He points to the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at the color. And see how shiny  it is? I could swear that's ice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This far south?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impossible. You can't have ice at  this latitude. Not unless...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other, Luke's excitement now leaping fr one to another of them. They're almost trembling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far away is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixteen kilometers northeast. Take  us twenty minutes to get there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (considers a moment) Let's send a packet to Micker. Then  we'll go check it out.

dialogues.speaker: AIRLOCK DOORS
dialogues.text: Slide back, REVEALING the crew in EVA suits, carrying gea They walk over to...

dialogues.speaker: THE FOUR-MAN ROVER
dialogues.text: The astronauts climb in through the hatch. The last one i pulls it shut behind him and locks the latches. We see Co and Luke check their screens and press some buttons. Luke puts the rover in drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the rover moves off across the rocky surface, dust kic up from the wheels, we get our first exterior glimpse of Mars One Base Camp. The main HAB UNIT looks like a huge t can with a conical top section; it connects to a separate inflated-bubble GREENHOUSE. There's also an OXYGEN STILL, PROPELLANT PLANT, and, on the other side, a couple hundre meters distant, the massive ERV (Earth Return Vehicle), w arrived as a separate, unmanned flight. Rows of SOLAR PANELS, arrayed on the ground, and an AMERI FLAG on a thin pole, about man-height, complete the scene

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vast, impressive, MULTI-SECTIONED SPACECRAFT is driftin majestically above Earth. The main hull displays both NAS and U.N. flag decals.

dialogues.speaker: CONTROL ROOM, (MMCR)
dialogues.text: We MOVE IN towards another of the station's segments, whi is dedicated entirely (as we see from more labels and  insignias) to the Mars Program: Control Room, Training an Living Quarters, and a Vehicle Docking and Launch Area, w Mars Two is already positioned for its eventual flight. W hear LUKE'S EXCITED VOICE, over speakers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a truly anomalous formation.  Looks like nothing we've seen so  far. The structure appears to be  crystalline, at least from the angle  displayed by ARES-8 ...

dialogues.speaker: INT. MMCR. DAY
dialogues.text: On a large CENTER DISPLAY SCREEN, we see Luke and the Mar One crew, sitting around their kitchen table in the Hab,  finishing lunch while taping this VIDEO MESSAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) We're all trying not to go too nuts  up here, but -- we think there's a  good chance this could be an extrusion  from some subsurface, geothermal  column of water. And if we're right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at his crew. They beam like cats who ate canarie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...then we've found the key to  permanent human colonization.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MMCR
dialogues.text: There's an EXCITED BUZZ among the assembled TECHNICIANS,  FLIGHT ENGINEERS, and SCIENTISTS. This would be a fantast epochal discovery.

dialogues.speaker: MCCONNELL
dialogues.text: Sits at the center console, wearing a headset. He's now t Mars One CAPCOM (Capsule Communicator), and his manner is brisk, efficient, all-business. A TECHNICIAN leans in for instructions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell geology and hydrology we need  to scramble on this. Full-court press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The technician nods, hurries away. McConnell, sharing the intense excitement of those around him, stares up at

dialogues.speaker: THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: Where Luke and his crew are still smiling, well knowing t excitement their bombshell will create.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, we'are going out to take a  closer look at it, try to get an  idea of its composition. (checks his watch) By the time you receive this, we  should be just about on-site.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARS. THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY
dialogues.text: The rover is a hundred meters away and moving fast TOWARD CAMERA. We BOOM DOWN to REVEAL Ares-8, still faithfully  holding its point, like an Irish Setter, with its video s WHIRRING OUT. The rover drives up and slows to a stop nearby. The hatch door cracks open and some dust vents out. The door opens the way and the astronauts climb out. They all look up in awe. We hear their voices ON RADIOS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ...

dialogues.speaker: THE MYSTERIOUS PEAK
dialogues.text: Gleams in the sun, dazzling white, its facets as planed a smooth as if an architect had drawn them. It pierces thro the topmost rubble at the near end of the big mountain -- isolated, butte-like giant, stretching two miles from lef to right in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: THE ASTRONAUTS
dialogues.text: Walk towards the mountain. There's a very deep, very low, staccato tone intruding over their headsets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone else hear that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like our antenna's out of  phase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you fix it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, skip, I can fix anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big talker. Renee, Sergei, let's  break out the radar, see what this  thing's made of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they go to their jobs, the deep, barely audible rumbli tone continues.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SPACE STATION. CORRIDOR OUTSIDE MMCR. DAY
dialogues.text: MULTINATIONAL CREWMEMBERS walk by, in the artificial grav of the busy station, as RAY BECK, mid-50s, approaches fro the opposite direction. Beck is the tough, crewcut, PR-sa head of the NASA Mars Program (ID'd by his name tag), and just now he's leading a covey of U.N. AMBASSADORS on a to The ambassadors, of both sexes, many nations, and all rac look as excited as schoolkids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and this is the Mars Mission  Control Room, nicknamed "Micker." I  understand a comm packet is incoming  from Mars One Base Camp, so you may  find this interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the doors, ushering his flock inside.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MMCR. DAY
dialogues.text: The ambassadors enter, oohing and ahhing over the impress array of gadgetry and personnel, and especially over the screen. Some of them start taking souvenir snaphots. The  NIGERIAN AMBASSADOR turns to Beck, whispering curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That man over there. He's in charge?

dialogues.speaker: MCCONNELL
dialogues.text: Who is surrounded by a KNOT OF TECHNICIANS, to whom he is giving quiet, precise instructions. They hover, then depa like so many eager bees.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: Smiles indulgently at the ambassador's misunderstanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, actually, that's Jim McConnell,  the CAPCOM. Our voice link to the  astronauts? Jim's been with the manned  Mars program since its inception.  One of our real pioneers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will he be going to Mars, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, no. This is as close as he gets.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: Luke and his crew have finished eating, and are clearing  away their dishes and leftovers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...anyway, that's about it. We'll  send another packet when we get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cote clears her throat, gives Luke a look. The others can barely conceal their grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right. One more thing. Today is  a very special day for a good friend  of ours, and I know he's there right  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McConnell looks at the screen, worried. What's Luke up to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, he hates it when any fuss is  made, so I won't mention his name...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look of relief comes over McConnell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...because the last thing in the  world I'd ever want to do is embarrass  someone like Jim McConnell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McConnell winces -- Dear God, no -- as, on the screen, Ki appears from OFF CAMERA holding a cupcake with a burning  candle stuck in it, and the Mars One crew starts SINGING  "Happy Birthday" to him. Loudly. And very off-key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, you Micker weasels, sing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon most everyone in MMCR is singing along -- even some the jolly ambassadors -- with the noticeable exception of Beck, who stiffens unhappily. McConnell is mortified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sings a line, then,  to CAMERA:) Hey, Ray! Take a look at him! Is he  all red with one of those fake "I'm- a-good-sport" grins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beck looks over at McConnell, who indeed is red in the fa with a fake "I'm-a-good-sport" grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And hey, you guys, check out Ray!  Does he have on one of his "This- wasn't-in-my-mission-plan" faces?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, Beck's smile is thin, sour, disapproving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing you can do about it, Ray!  We're a hundred million miles away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke and the crew finish singing the song. Luke raises th cupcake in a toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy Birthday, Jimbo! Make a wish!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and his crew lean in, blow out the candle. They laugh applaud, then wave goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catch you again soon. Take care,  buddy. End of transmission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke reaches out, turns OFF the CAMERA, and the display s GOES BLACK. Beck turns, his gaze locking with McConnell's. He's annoy as if this violation of protocol were somehow McConnell's fault. McConnell returns his stare coolly.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARS. THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY
dialogues.text: Cote stands by a display screen mounted on the rover. Kir has a big radar gun on a tripod, pointing at the mountain Luke turns to Cote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? What's under there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Je ne sais pas. I... I think there's  something wrong with the equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, it can't be right. It says...  it says there's metal under there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke doesn't understand. He walks up to look at the displ screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points) There's ten, twelve meters of rubble  and sand, and then... solid metal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't make any sense. You're  reading a vein of ore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) No. It's under the whole mountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The deep pulsing tone continues. Luke frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick, could the problem with the  antenna be interfering?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cote and Kirov) Try it closer and up the power. I'll  watch the screen.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MMCR. DAY
dialogues.text: McConnell is taping an audio message to be sent to Mars a the rest of MMCR looks on. Beck is gone. So are the U. N. ambassadors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, we're all pretty stoked about  that formation you spotted, Mars  One. The folks in the geology and  hydrology back rooms are going over  your images and comparing them to  every photomap they've got.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARS. THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY
dialogues.text: Cote and Kirov are close to the foot of the mountain,  resetting the radar gun on its tripod. The deep vibrating tone continues. Luke is some distance away, by the rover. He looks at Wil who's still working on the rover's antenna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick, how we coming on that antenna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goin' as fast as I can, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cote and Kirov are having some trouble with the switches the radar gun. They turn towards Luke and Willis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Nick. Come show me how stupid I  am. I can't get this to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willis looks at Luke. Luke nods -- Go help them. Willis s towards the radar gun.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MMCR. DAY
dialogues.text: McConnell is handed a slip of paper, glances at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medical wants me to remind you that  you're three days late on your blood  tests. I know they're a bore, but  you've got to get them done, or  else... or else I don't know what.  Just do them, okay?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARS. THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY
dialogues.text: Willis, Cote, and Kirov get the radar gun up and running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All set here, chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke sidles over to the display screen on the rover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Crank up the juice and let's  see what's in this sucker.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MMCR. DAY
dialogues.text: McConnell checks over his clipboard list of updates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that's about it for business.  But on a personal note, be advised  that, ah, none of you can sing worth  a damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUGHTER in the MMCR.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARS. THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY
dialogues.text: Luke watches the screen on the rover, as, by the mound...

dialogues.speaker: KIROV
dialogues.text: Flips a switch on the radar gun, then swivels its muzzle  slowly across the near slope of the mountain. We hear and feel the radar signal. The immediate result is that the  pulsing tone we've been hearing suddenly stops.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Looks up from the display screen. A puzzled expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did that stop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A split-second later, he gets his answer. We hear a WHOOS a mighty rushing of wind, as

dialogues.speaker: A GIGANTIC, TRANSLUCENT CYLINDER
dialogues.text: Starts to swirl and rise, straight up from the top or the mountain, at its center. As it swirls, the cylinder picks debris -- pebbles, sand -- from the sediment-encrusted su of the slopes.

dialogues.speaker: THE FOUR ASTRONAUTS
dialogues.text: Stare up at this spectacle, awed. A cyclone? Some kind of energy wave? They have no idea. At the moment they're too fascinated to even be scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the whirling cylinder rise, higher and higher,  perfectly straight, until in just moments it's as tall as skyscraper. As it rises, it gains speed and power, narrow at its top into a conical vortex. It's sucking up so much dirt, so many rocks -- even small boulders now -- that th accumulating debris begins to darken its swirling, transl outer "skin".

dialogues.speaker: THE ASTRONAUTS
dialogues.text: Exchange amazed glances. Can't believe their eyes...

dialogues.speaker: INT. MMCR. DAY
dialogues.text: McConnell still hovers by the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honestly, Luke, if you guys don't  have anything better to do with your  time, I can make some suggestions to  mission medical. There are worse  things than blood tests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUGHTER and GROANS from the staff in MMCR.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARS. THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY
dialogues.text: Luke, still staring in fascination, becomes aware of sand and pebbles flashing past his helmet. From behind. He tur

dialogues.speaker: SAND PATTERS AGAINST HIS FACEPLATE
dialogues.text: As the nearby landscape BLURS. The vacuuming effect is  becoming more general across the area. More violent.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE IS ALARMED
dialogues.text: And the spell is broken. He keys his throat mike, his lip moving, but no sound can be heard over the ROARING WIND. waves his arms, motioning for the others to back away, to the rover. Wind whips at their EVA suits as they obey him retreating. Luke, backing away himself, is afraid to take his eyes of the cylinder. Then he sees that one man -- Willis -- hasn't moved. In f he's busily snapping photographs of the cylinder. Luke hu over to him, tugs his sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIS LOWERS HIS CAMERA
dialogues.text: But still stares up, transfixed, like a man face to face  with a cobra. Luke follows the young astronaut's frighten gaze, and his own eyes widen as he sees

dialogues.speaker: THE TOP OF THE VORTEX
dialogues.text: Beginning to tilt down, then coil sideways. Suddenly they looking into the huge open "mouth" of it, as sand and roc fly into the swirling darkness... The monstrous, gaping maw slithers down over the rim of t mountain, turning this way, then that. Seeking them. And  then, with horrifying precision, it locks in on the littl group of astronauts. And lunges towards them...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARS. THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY
dialogues.text: Luke and Willis turn, running as hard as they can towards the rover. But the suction is so great, it's as if they'r held back by wires. The ground itself is SHAKING, RUMBLING, as earthquakes be to open fissures across the plain. The ROAR of the vortex the GROANING of the earth, are like an onrushing freight  train...

dialogues.speaker: AHEAD OF THEM
dialogues.text: In the maelstrom of flying debris, they can barely make o Cote and Kirov, still retreating, leaning back with all t strength against the suction, while staring up, aghast. Suddenly a hurtling rock, the size of a basketball, smash into Cote's helmet from behind, crushing it and killing h instantly. Blood sprays into the wind, immediately  crystallizing, in the sub-zero atmosphere, into red pelle

dialogues.speaker: LUKE, HORRIFIED, FLINGS HIS ARM UP
dialogues.text: As bloody hail patters against his faceplate and forearm. instant later he sees

dialogues.speaker: KIROV
dialogues.text: Snatched up by the wind, then swept past him, in a terrif blur, arms and legs flailing, mouth open in a silent scre as he vanishes...

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUND AT LUKE'S FEET
dialogues.text: Abruptly opens, and he slides into a fissure. Scrabbling  frantically with his gloved hands, he manages to momentar arrest his fall, gripping the edge of the fault line, wit his helmet and one elbow thrust over its lip. The air is  almost solidly choked with debris, deadly boulders bound  over him, and torrents of cascading sand are burying him  alive...

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Barely conscious, as he watches, for a horrifying final  instant, as...

dialogues.speaker: HIS LAST CREWMAN, WILLIS
dialogues.text: Is sucked bodily into the black maw of the vortex, spinni and tumbling like a rag doll...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIS'S FACE
dialogues.text: His features grotesquely distorted by the forces tearing him, before suddenly his faceplate is sprayed with blood, and...

dialogues.speaker: LUKE'S POV
dialogues.text: Willis's spacesuit explodes, his entire body disintegrati into a million bits, which instantly disappear into the  hellish maelstrom. And then that maelstrom itself, just a abruptly... STOPS. Vanishes. There is an instant, ringing SILENCE, as awesome in its o way as the roaring storm itself had been...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the plain, as the last pebbles, released from suction, pitter down, bouncing. Swirls of dust and sand drift away settling gently. The harsh orange landscape is once again calm, peaceful. And then, from the direction of the nearby mountain, we h another sound: the deep bass pulsing rumble returns.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MMCR. DAY
dialogues.text: As McConnell finishes his message to Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, and I talked to Debra. She and  Bobby are doing fine. Said to tell  you, they're, ah, they're on their  "third time through the book, page -- (glances at a note) -- page 125." They send their love  and say take care of yourself. Same  from us here, buddy. Till next time,  then. End of transmission.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARS. THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY
dialogues.text: MOVING ANGLE, the CAMERA EXPLORING ground zero, as the ba pulsing rumble continues... WE PASS the Rover, canted sideways into a little crater,  with its canopy missing, one axle fractured, but miraculo still with all four wheels... WE PASS faithful little ARES-8, lying on its side, partia crushed under a boulder. It gives a final, pitiful WHINE, its video snout slowly extending, then dies. And finally come to the area where the fissure had been, and see

dialogues.speaker: THE FISSURE HAS BEEN FILLED IN
dialogues.text: Leaving only a slender crease of umber sand. No sign of L The pulsing rumble continues, over, as we see

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An extraordinary sight, seen from high in the air, lookin back down. Staring up at us from the bottom of a shallow  crater, scoured clean of its aeons of accumulated silt an rubble, is a structure resembling a vast humanoid Face. The surface is gleaming white, apparently metallic. The  features are suggested by intricately interlocking planes slopes, ramps. The "eyes" -- hatches of some kind? -- are closed, and the overall expression is eerily calm, but  terrible in its power, like some ancient tribal mask. We see the Face clearly for only a few beats before thick scudding clouds OBSCURE it, but the deep, pulsing rumble  continues, low and insistent...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're inside the Mars Two spacecraft, which is still in i docked position alongside the Space Station. Woody Blake, wearing a NASA jumpsuit, floats up into the  cockpit in Zero-G, studying a thick manual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reads) "Problem: Hatch door malfunction,  backup power fail, manual override  fail. Solution: Replace circuit  breaker 907B."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He straps into the pilot's seat, staring at an electrical junction box at one end of the console.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... Piece of cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He swings open the housing, revealing a bewildering tangl of fuses and wires. He sighs heavily, as Terri drifts up  beside him, also in a jumpsuit, and straps into the co-pi seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, who dreams up these nightmares?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't try to change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not! We're talking about your  sister's wedding, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very funny. We're talking about  dancing lessons. Before my sister's  wedding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, do you mind? I've got a  catastrophic power failure here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He peers into the housing with exaggerated concern. But  Terri's not so easily sidetracked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody, we're a married couple. Would  it kill you to invite me out on the  floor once in awhile?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I danced with you at our wedding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not talking about shuffling your  feet around while you grab my butt.  I mean real dancing. Cha-cha, rhumba,  jitterbug --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Face it, honey, some couples dance,  some go to Mars. That's life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious. We've got two more months  in this training rotation, but just  as soon as we get home, we're starting  lessons. If we never dance, people  will think there's something wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they see me dance, they'll know  there's something wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reaching past him, she pulls out the required breaker. As reacts, surprised, she smiles, despite her exasperation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are such a lug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overhead, an intercom CRACKLES. We hear PHIL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cockpit, this is Control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Control, this is Cockpit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Terri, they want us all back in  the Station. Report to Micker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who says report to Micker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little men who live in my head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil, c'mon! We just started this  drill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody, it was Ray Beck. He told me  to round up the team. Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody and Terri exchange a worried look. What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SPACE STATION. MMCR. DAY
dialogues.text: A crisis atmosphere prevails. The big room is more crowde than we've ever seen it, with ENGINEERS and MANAGERS hurr by, huddling in tense, conferring knots, or muttering  feverishly into microphones. On the center screen, a giant image of Mars. A frantic fl of green numbers crawls above and below this, and the sit of the Mars One Base Camp is marked in blinking red.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY AND HIS CREW
dialogues.text: Are staring up at this screen, appalled. McConnell and Be stand nearby, briefing them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, at 1417, the X-band continuous  data stream from Mars went silent.  All data -- med, environmental,  everything -- suddenly stopped. While  we were trying to figure out what  the hell went wrong, we got a signal  from the folks at the Large Array at  Soccoro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the same moment we lost the data  stream, they picked up an intense  burst of energy from Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, "intense"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Catastrophic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks are exchanged among the Mars Two crew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the crew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The level of energy in the pulse...  didn't seem survivable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the REMO? It went into  Mars orbit last week. Maybe that  could give us some clue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good thinking, Woody. That's just  what we tried next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans over, punches buttons on a keyboard.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE CENTER SCREEN
dialogues.text: An orange dot can be seen in its orbital ellipse around M leaving a glowing electronic trail. This dot gets isolate in a viewing box, then enlarged and rotated into the comp animated image of a small, ugly, industrial-looking unman cargo craft, labelled "REMO."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Resupply Module checked out fine.  No instrument failures, no change in  status. Orbit holding steady. But  there was something else. The REMO'S  computer contained an uplink message --  a very faint, highly distorted  transmission from Mars One Base Camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone's alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The message is almost indecipherable.  Two teams are still working on it.  You better see for yourselves.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MMCR. DAY
dialogues.text: FINGERS press buttons on a console. McConnell, Woody, Ter and Phil are crowded around a monitor with Beck and two w TECHNICIANS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still concentrating on the audio. We  managed to bring out a couple more  words, but we've got a long way to  go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show us whatever you've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The technician nods, then gestures to his assistant who h a play button.

dialogues.speaker: A MONITOR
dialogues.text: Black for a moment, then static. Out of this static comes faint image of Luke, sitting alone at the Hab kitchen tab He looks awful -- dried blood on his face, bloodshot eyes The image is blurry, heavily streaked, and most of what h says is lost in waves of static.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...make this quick... may be only ch-- (long section of static) ...to the site, when we... hit us  just as we... --thers are all dead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody, Terri and Phil look at each other -- Oh, God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (following more static) ...low sound that we couldn't  understand. Then all of a sudden  there was this terrib... (another long burst  of static) ...--stems are holding up for now,  but I don't know how long I can...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The monitor screen GOES BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody and his crew stare at the screen, stunned. This is catastrophe almost too huge to grasp.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SPACE STATION. DAY
dialogues.text: As Beck leads McConnell and the other shaken astronauts d a corridor, Phil pauses, seeing...

dialogues.speaker: A SOBBING TECHNICIAN
dialogues.text: At her desk. TWO CO-WORKERS are trying to comfort her. On of these women looks up, and her reddened eyes meet...

dialogues.speaker: PHIL'S EYES
dialogues.text: He looks back at her, haunted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did Luke mean by a "low sound?"

dialogues.speaker: INT. SPACE STATION. DAY
dialogues.text: In an otherwise empty lounge, the astronauts clutch Styro coffee cups. Beck stands nearby. Through a large viewport behind them, stars glitter against the inky blackness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this was a earthquake, as we're  now assuming, there's usually an  auditory component.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that energy pulse they picked up  in New Mexico...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Electromagnetic emission. Not uncommon  with large-scale geophysical  phenomena.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) Causing this kind of damage? I don't  buy it. We're missing something here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McConnell and Woody exchange a glance... Woody's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke must be in pretty bad shape if  he hasn't blasted out of there in  the Earth Return Vehicle. That thing's  designed so even one crew member  could fly it back to Earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if Luke was in great shape, he  couldn't get home. That energy pulse  would've fried the ERV'S computers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other than the computers, how do we  think the ERV fared?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, so far our modelling says it  should be in pretty good shape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which means it's gonna be up to us  to get new motherboards, drives, and  software to Mars. As fast as we can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McConnell looks at him, nods. They're on the same wavelen But Beck is more cautious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, slow down. It's gonna take us  weeks just to analyze this data.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, but meanwhile, we've gotta be  working up a mission plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke needs us now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke may already be dead. And even  if he's not, it's doubtful he's going  to be able to transmit again. So we  wouldn't know whether it's safe to  land until you were almost there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about SIMA?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terri looks at Phil -- SIMA?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Saturn Imaging Probe. It's going  to slingshot around Mars on its way  through the solar system. It could  be retasked to take pictures, read  radiation levels at Mars One Base  Camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good idea Phil. If SIMA tells us  Luke hasn't survived and it's not  safe to land, we swing around Mars  and come right back home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. We can design the mission to  have a free return capability. It's  a long trip, but if you don't land  it's the best option.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're getting ahead of ourselves.  You're forgetting the bigger problem. (they look at him) The orbits are all wrong. Our first  decent launch window is almost eight  months from now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we can go earlier and get there  faster if we reconfigure the payload  for extra fuel. We've modelled that,  Ray. I've modelled it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On paper, yeah. But those stresses  have never been tested in space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ship can take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't thinking of just the ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tense beat. Again we sense the test of wills between th two tough-minded men, once good friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know the protocols for a Mars  Recovery Mission better than anybody,  because I helped design them. And  I'm saying these guys can do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right, Ray. We've got a real  shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause with beck weighing the odds. He looks at Woody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me an updated mission plan by  0800 tomorrow. Then I'll put it in  the works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have it by 0600.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Woody, Phil and Terri, who are just as eager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McConnell exits followed by Terri and Phil, but as Beck s out, too, Woody stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chief, could I have a word?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beck looks at him a moment, nods.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SPACE STATION. MMCR. DAY
dialogues.text: In a quiet corner, Woody and Beck are alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've no longer got the right crew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) What do you mean? Bjornstrom can be  up here on the next shuttle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bjornstrom is a geologist. He's good,  but not for this. My people just  lost eight months of training. This  is a different mission, with a  different objective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't been given authorization  for a mission yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But when you are, it ought to be  given the best chance for success. I  want McConnell to fly right seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beck's expression hardens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's no longer on mission status.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Because you washed him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He washed himself out. He only had  to pass a few more psych evaluations,  but he refused to take them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, he's the best pilot I ever saw,  and you've got him benched at a desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody has to pass the psych  prelims. No exceptions. Jim knew  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie was his wife. He didn't want  to lie on a couch and share her with  strangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was his call. But I had to make  one too. It was tough as hell, but  I'd do it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife wasted away in front of his  eyes. What was he supposed to do?  Suck it up? Get with the program?  What was his crime? That he was upset?  That he cried...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't trust him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beck and Woody stare at each other. A long tense beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his voice softer) Not in a crisis... I'm sorry Woody,  but Jim lost his edge. Are you gonna  stand there and tell me Jim McConnell  is the same man he was two years  ago? You want me to bet four more  lives on that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This stops Woody, just for a beat. Then makes him press o harder, with even greater intensity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Maggie died, yeah, it knocked  the shit out of him. It knocked the  hell out of all of us. But you know  and I know that he's still the best  we've got. He and Maggie wrote the  book on Mars. He's got more hours in  the sims than the rest of us put  together. Ray, we can do this. Give  me McConnell as co-pilot, and we  will bring Luke home. And that's a  promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beck looks back at him, his features taunt.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SPACE STATION. MMCR. DAY
dialogues.text: Woody, Terri, and Phil stand at the edge of the big contr room, waiting and watching, in a tense silence, as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beck and McConnell are huddled together at the CAPCOM's  console. Other personnel have moved away, giving them roo Both men are seated, leaning forward, with McConnell list intently, while Beck does most of the talking, very quiet After a moment McConnell looks up in surprise. His eyes s the room till they find

dialogues.speaker: WOODY'S FACE
dialogues.text: Woody looks back at him, nods: C'mon, man. Take it.

dialogues.speaker: MCCONNELL'S OWN FACE
dialogues.text: Is a study in conflicting emotions. But after a moment he masters his feelings, turns back toward Beck. A few more  quiet words are exchanged, then Beck offers his hand.  McConnell hesitates, then shakes it. Both men rise, and  McConnell turns again to look towards

dialogues.speaker: WOODY, TERRI, AND PHIL
dialogues.text: Who react with relief, glad that he's now a part of their crew. Woody grins, giving him a thumb's up.

dialogues.speaker: MCCONNELL'S FACE
dialogues.text: As he smiles. Then he starts towards them, with a new ene in his step, a new sense of confidence and purpose. And a he WALKS TOWARDS US, PASSING OUT OF FRAME...

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DEEP SPACE. MARS RECOVERY. DAY
dialogues.text: An infinite canopy of stars. After a moment, some of them begin to be BLOTTED OUT as

dialogues.speaker: A SPACESHIP
dialogues.text: Glides INTO VIEW. "MARS RECOVERY" (formerly Mars Two) loo much like its sister craft on Mars: a conical cockpit mou above a "tuna can" crew Hab module.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER TITLE
dialogues.text: The entire lower deck forms a segmented section of the hu that rotates on bearings to provide artificial gravity; w see window ports spinning past, then an American flag emb Behind this lower deck, in an extending network of struts like the abdomen of a dragonfly, are the three huge round PROPELLANT TANKS. Then vast, delicate-looking rectangular SOLAR PANELS, which sweep out to either side of the ship; these also bear the dish of the earth-pointing HI-GAIN  ANTENNA. And finally comes the great mass of the ENGINE B housed within a curving AEROSHELL; three hatches in the  aeroshell can open to allow the main thrusters to fire th for a mid-course burn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the forward section of the ship, APPROACHING a viewpor in the EVA airlock chamber. Inside, we can see Phil leani forward, concentrating on some task...

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script. INT. EVA AIRLOCK. DAY. A BUNCH OF M&MS Are floating in mid-air, forming an intricate 3D pattern. the EVA airlock, it's zero G. Phil, strapped into a chair by a galley counter, is just  completing this weightless puzzle by placing a final blue M&M. He looks bored, sluggish. In the b.g., Terri is over a microscope. McConnell emerges from the core tunnel, behind them, comi up from the lower Hab, then pushes off from the ladder,  floating towards Phil. He grins, admiring Phil's obsessiv handiwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That... is the exact chemical  composition of my ideal woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Used to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He plucks out a couple of the M&Ms as he drifts by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McConnell grins, snacking on the M&Ms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil looks sadly at his floating model.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A frog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McConnell and Terri laugh as Phil starts scarfing down th rest of the M&Ms. Swooping at them with both hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess now we have our answer to  the effects of long-term  interplanetary travel on the human  mind. The answer is Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) I'm gonna get an update on SIMA. It  should be just about close enough to  start capturing some surface images.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's drifted to another short ladder, and now grabs it, s up to the cockpit, atop the Hab.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COCKPIT. DAY
dialogues.text: As McConnell appears in the cockpit, he sees Woody by the forward instrumentation panel, looking at a monitor. The  cockpit is also zero G.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Skip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McConnell pulls himself forward.

dialogues.speaker: MONITOR
dialogues.text: MARS completely fills the screen. Surface details are cle visible. Something is moving down there, an amorphous bro swirl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you make of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dust storm. Southern hemisphere,  coming from the east... Big fella,  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Headed for Chryse Planitia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup. Could get a little hairy just  about landing time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McConnell pulls back from the screen, looks at Woody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have to be ready to move fast.  Maybe even advance our ETA. Those  things can cover the whole planet,  and last up to a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. They both hope he's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When does SIMA do her fly-by?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow morning, about 0600. That's  when we find out whether we came all  this way for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exchange a glance. Woody's right, but the thought is too terrible to dwell on. McConnell looks back at Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) My money's on Luke.

dialogues.speaker: A DIGITAL CLOCK
dialogues.text: Just turning over to read "0545."

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Pulls her gaze away from these numbers. Judging from her  redrimmed eyes, it's been a long, anxious night. Restless looking to distract herself, she reaches for a test tube blood, straps it into a centrifuge, sets it spinning. Nea is her electron microscope.

dialogues.speaker: MCCONNELL, (LOWER HAB)
dialogues.text: Lies on his cot in his own cubicle, with the door closed. The lower hab has artificial gravity (AG) and McConnell c move normally. Hands behind his head, he stares at his bu

dialogues.speaker: PHOTO OF A WOMAN
dialogues.text: Rests there, in its leather travel frame. Beautiful, smil dark-haired: MAGGIE MCCONNELL. Her face glows with  intelligence and energy.

dialogues.speaker: MCCONNELL
dialogues.text: Shifts his eyes. The clock on his bulkhead reads "0546."

dialogues.speaker: PHIL, (LOWER HAB)
dialogues.text: Stands in the communal bathroom, still in his pajamas, a  towel around his shoulders, brushing his teeth. He glance at another digital clock, which reads "0547." Shakes his  head impatiently. He looks back into the mirror, then is  surprised to hear MUSIC lilting incongruously over the  loudspeakers: Elvis Presley's "Blue Moon."

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: INT. EVA AIRLOCK. DAY
dialogues.text: Phil floats in through the connecting tunnel, then stops  himself at a handhold. He grins, charmed by the sight of

dialogues.speaker: WOODY AND TERRI DANCING
dialogues.text: Like a weightless Fred and Ginger. Woody is surprisingly  good at this. Enthusiastic, unselfconscious. He sweeps Terri gallantly about the little cabin, pushing off from every handy surface, even guiding her into some  passable twirls and dips. She laughs, shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What brought this on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zero-G. My last chance to be graceful.  Once we're in Mars gravity, it's  back to shuffling my feet and grabbing  her butt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take what I can get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grins, kisses his ear, as Phil turns, sees

dialogues.speaker: MCCONNELL
dialogues.text: Who has now arrived, is also watching the dancing couple. twinge of sadness crosses his features. But when his eyes meet Phil's, he shakes off the feeling and manages a smil Aren't they something? Over the music, they hear a CHIRP from the SHIP'S COMPUTE then an announcement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attention. Incoming packet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all look at each other. This is it! Woody spins over a console, shuts off the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's SIMA.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COCKPIT. DAY. MINUTES LATER
dialogues.text: The crew is gathered around a display screen. The lights dim, reflecting up off their faces. By their expressions, can tell the news is not good.

dialogues.speaker: THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: It's a color, high-resolution satellite image of the Mars One Base Camp. Ghostly, dust-covered. No signs of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks deserted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's still standing, though. So is  the ERV. And look, there's the  greenhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know Luke survived for at least a  few hours. Question is, are there  any signs of recent activity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all scan the screen. Phil spots something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs a stylus and touches the screen. They all look.

dialogues.speaker: THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: Using where the stylus touches the screen as the focal po the image enlarges. THREE LONGISH DIRT PILES appear, some fifty meters from the hab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are those?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McConnell gets it first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all realize he's right. They sit back, stunned. But  then Phil has another thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on. There's only three. That  means --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means Luke must still be --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It just means there was nobody  left to bury him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This quiets everyone for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check the radiation levels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil keys in some commands and data pops up onscreen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to the disaster site.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil uses the stylus to bring MORE IMAGES into view. The  frame moves over the terrain in the direction of the Face first in SWIFT BLURS, then slowing. Scattered rock debris come into view. The IMAGE ARRIVES where the mountain was, and they see... Debris in every direction, NEAT SPIRALS of it now, droppe uncannily into place, like some massive earth sculpture. if - but this makes no sense -- it had been swirled towar a LARGE CRATER. The crater itself is a perfect circle. Th FOCUS on the CENTER OF THE CRATER, but the image gets  distorted by STATIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Magnetic interference?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil tweaks the stylus, but the image won't clear up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to infrared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil works the keyboard.

dialogues.speaker: THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: Goes to INFRARED, reading heat, The middle of the IMAGE,  where the Face is, is still distorted, refusing focus.

dialogues.speaker: THE ASTRONAUTS
dialogues.text: Sit back, exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be a problem with SIMA. I don't  see how an earthquake, six months  ago, could give us this kind of  distortion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was no quake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans closer, staring intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what the hell was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McConnell shakes his head. But his every sense is engaged he's like a predator just sighting his prey for the first time. We see in his eyes an utter determination to unlock this secret.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SPACE. DAY
dialogues.text: Mars Recovery is speeding ever closer to Mars, which now  looms large, a dusty red mysterious sphere.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MARS RECOVERY. LOWER HAB. DAY
dialogues.text: McConnell and crew are eating dinner while they watch a t message from MMCR.

dialogues.speaker: MONITOR SCREEN
dialogues.text: As Ray Beck addresses them. Other NASA STAFFERS, twenty o more, have crowded in behind him, and we sense their grea hopefulness and high spirits; the whole team's triumph is tantalizingly close now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to continue analyzing  this data and try to determine what  the problem is with those images.  Frankly, we're just as stumped as  you guys, but we'll keep on it. (glancing around) We agree that the evidence of the  graves is inconclusive and that a  ground search is advisable.
